I can understand the Minister's frustration as his statement was a rehash of what he said on the budget with a few new elements introduced to encourage budding entrepreneurs but he had no reply to the unemployment problem. He encapsulated what the Minister for Enterprise and Employment, Deputy Quinn, said this afternoon in regard to what he would do about unemployment. He said the county enterprise boards were the only measure which could do something extra to encourage employment.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Richard Bruton responded in his document — which I encourage the Minister to read if he wants to get good points from the Opposition — to the services sector and pinpointed how that sector has been neglected down through the years. There has been an over emphasis on new measures to encourage manufacturing activity. We have failed to recognise the great potential within the services sector. Deputy Richard Bruton does the Fine Gael Party justice in producing this document. It gives a boost to the services sector and I encourage the Minister to take many of its ideas on board. A businessman in Newcastle West said to me recently that at this stage he almost feels like a criminal. Not only is he harassed by social welfare officers, he is harassed by the tax man and it is almost regarded as dishonorable to make a few bob. That is what the business people are up against and that is what they are putting up with in the services sector. Because of the way in which things have evoloved in recent years he has a point. About two weeks ago in my own town of Newcastle West we had a blitz where the whole community knew that ten or 12 people were in the area, calling to every business. The Minister may say they have a job to do in regard to compliance and so on but I assure him it does not encourage those businessmen to take on extra employees.
Debate adjourned.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Dublin Zoo.

Speaker.P: In July 1990 the Government established a committee of inquiry to investigate into Dublin Zoo. This committee produced its report, the Doyle report, named after its chairman, Mr. Mick Doyle. Over three years later the Doyle report has still not been released and the Government has continued to support and subsidise the current zoo authorities, who, according to the report, should be made accountable.

The report, a copy of which I have with me, makes very interesting reading. It is stated that it is published by the Stationery Office and is to be purchased through any bookseller or directly from Government Publications Sales Office. However, it is unavailable. Tomorrow week, on 27 October 1993, at a special general meeting the zoo authority is seeking to amend the laws of the society relating to its dissolution and to transfer the society's assets, including the animals, to a new company, the Zoological Society of Ireland Limited, thus I understand, removing itself even further from accountability. In this swift move it has already been committed Government funds. I have heard the sum of £10 million mentioned but I would like to have that figure clarified. I understand the money has been committed by the Minister for Finance without reference to the findings of the Government inquiry or any need to publish those findings.

MainHeading.P: The zoo authorities, supported by Government neglect, hope to hijack the national zoo, limit its own liability and pursue what I believe to be personal agendas, not in keeping with the zoological society's constitution, under the pretext of limiting members' liability. Under the zoo's current regulations, its dissolution requires a 40 per cent attendance of members and a two-thirds majority vote. This is the best protection afforded to the members. Until such time as the report of the inquiry is published properly and the public and Members of this House are allowed the opportunity to debate it, the zoo authorities should not be allowed any further diminution of their responsibilities. On 27 October the president of the Royal Zoological Society of Ireland and the council will seek to dismantle this protection, transfer authority to a meeting of not fewer than 30 members, compared to 3,000 under the present rules. They further propose to transfer all assets to themselves and their nominees as a new authority, thus disenfranchising all other members and rendering the inquiry into Dublin Zoo — an extensive inquiry where people gave the benefit of their expertise — academic and redundant.

The Taoiseach promised this country an open Government and accountability. In order to fulfil this promise in relation to the Royal Zoological Society, no transfer of assets, dismantling of members' protection or further Government support for the current zoo authorities should be allowed until the Government inquiry into Dublin Zoo is published and released and, most importantly, acted upon by this Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Treacy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: As I stated in a reply to a parliamentary question on this issue last week, the Doyle report dealing with the future of Dublin Zoo was presented to the Minister for Education, who decided against publishing it pending consideration of substantial issues arising from it. One issue concerned the allocation of future responsibility for the zoo. The Doyle report, in making a recommendation that a Department should have a role in relation to the zoo, did not indicate which Department this should be. Having considered this issue the Government recently agreed to transfer responsibility for the zoo from the Department of Education to the Department of Finance.

I have since examined the recommendations of the Doyle report and can straight away affirm my agreement with the conclusion that there is a future for Dublin Zoo. I have therefore asked the Office of Public Works to prepare a plan to ensure the future of the zoo having regard to the Doyle report and the following four objectives: 1. to operate to commercial standards so that State subsidies can be minimised; 2. to continue the captive breeding of endangered species and the presentation of species to foster an appreciation of nature and global conservation; 3. to achieve animal care which meets the highest international standards within appropriate space requirements; 4. to contribute to the tourism and recreational potential of Dublin by providing quality visitor facilities and programmes.

I hope the plan will be available early in the new year and that after it is considered by Government the conclusions of the Doyle report and the outline of the plan will be made public. I do not envisage that any further grants will be made available to the zoo until the plan is examined by Government.

On the question of the Zoo Society setting up a new company, this is entirely a matter for them. Their offer of two places on the new company for two senior civil servants was accepted. It provides the opportunity for the State to assess the performance of the new company to ensure that any State investments are in accordance with agreed objectives and to an agreed plan. The move does not preempt the findings of the plan, which will thoroughly assess all aspects of the zoo from animal welfare to organisation and financial performance.

MainHeading.P: I am aware that there have been criticisms at the delay in reaching final conclusions on the Doyle report. However, now that the decision has been made to transfer responsibility for the zoo to the Department of Finance, there will be no delay in formulating a plan which will clearly indicate what steps need to be taken to guarantee the future of the zoo. The plan will have to address issues such as extra land, future State subsidy and other matters. On the question of extra land, it is too early to say, however, what the plan will show and we should not anticipate its findings.

With regard to financial subsidy, prior to 1985 State support for the zoo was very modest. Given the financial difficulties of the zoo between 1985 and 1992, grants totalling £1,620,000 were made to keep it viable. The money was not wasted. It provided the zoo with the chance to effect changes to improve its financial performance and with the success of the Dino Live exhibition this year the zoo should not need financial support in 1993 to assist its operations. It is nevertheless a fact of life that most zoos in the EC require some subvention, particularly given their important role in conservation and education. The plan will show how the financial and commercial performance of the zoo can be maximised so that such subventions, if any, can be minimised.

I stress that a well run modern zoo has a vital role to play in global conservation. This was confirmed in the Doyle report and the view is supported by the foremost non-governmental conservation organisation in the world, the IUCN, who emphasises the vital role zoos have in captive breeding programmes to ensure the viability of endangered species.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Drinks Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: I thank you, Sir, for giving me the opportunity to raise this matter on the Adjournment, a matter which is causing concern particularly in Dublin city. We are all aware that under the Competition Act it is illegal for two or more businesses to come together to agree a price rise. Is it reasonable to expect the ordinary drinker to believe that the announcement by the Licensed Vintners Association to increase the price of a pint by 3p and the price of a half one by 3p is not collusion? It is unreasonable to expect them to believe otherwise. The Director of Consumer Affairs stated on public record that he believes there is a prima facie case that some collusion is taking place. It is regrettable that only the Minister can deal with this matter and that the director cannot do so himself.

This 3p increase is being imposed on top of a 2p increase imposed by Guinness during the summer. At that time the publicans tried to block the increase imposed by Guinness and it is disappointing to note they have switched from gamekeeper to poacher in such a short time. According to the consumer price index, the price of alcoholic drink increased by 3.3 per cent during the last 12 months, more than twice the increase of any other consumer product. The latest increase will push that figure up to 6 per cent, at least three times the rate of inflation. All other business had to honour commitments under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress and deal with rising costs, but they have been able to avoid such large price increases.

MainHeading.P: The present increases are not due to increased taxes because for the first time in a number of years the budget did not impose a tax on drink. At that time the Minister for Finance indicated that he hoped the trade would follow his lead, but in this case his words have proved hollow. It is difficult not to believe there is an element of collusion attached to the increase. It is only two weeks since the wage increase that is supposed to have triggered the increase in the price of drink was accepted, and it is difficult to believe that the Licensed Vintners Association is unaware of what is happening on the ground. It is much more likely that it is trying to give a lead to its members in a collusive manner.

This matter illustrates how toothless are the consumer watchdogs we have set up, because neither the Competition Authority nor the Director of Consumer Affairs have the power to deal with the problem. Instead, the law quite unrealistically expects the aggrieved drinker to take a case to the High Court. Our only fallback is if the Minister can indicate tonight that he will investigate the matter and take action if necessary. The enforcement of competition law should not lie in political hands. We should give our consumer watchdogs power to act without fear or favour, they should not have to look over their shoulders to see if the Minister will promote an investigation or take action in a matter.

Another matter of concern during the past week is the fact that the giant Irish Distillers Group swallowed up Cooley Distillers with the loss of 29 jobs. It is evident that the sole aim is to reduce competition in the drinks industry, because they immediately closed down the operation of the Cooley distillery. That is an equally worrying trend in the spirits market. Is it good for the consumer or this country that such a competitor should disappear? I would like to hear the Minister's views on that matter because that type of takeover requires ministerial approval before a decision is taken.

In the past the price of drink has brought down Governments. Therefore, we cannot take this issue lightly; it is important for many consumers and I would like to know how the Government proposes to deal with the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. N. Treacy) Noel Treacy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. N. Treacy)
Speaker.P: At the outset let me say that I, as well as Minister Quinn and the Government as a whole, share the concern of the Deputy in this matter. The outrage reflected in newspaper comment over the past two days is certainly justified as the licensed trade has once again proposed to raise its prices.

The rules of competition, which are now generally well known, prohibit price agreements and concerted practices which restrict competition. The prohibition includes decisions by associations which directly or indirectly fix purchase or selling prices and applies to price collusion or any arrangement to raise prices in unison. Price fixing in any of its guises is manifestly unacceptable and shows a blatant disregard for the competition law and for consumers. Although the price of alcoholic drink can and does vary between licensed premises, a decision by the trade association which causes prices to increase by a uniform rate needs some explanation.

It is certainly not in the interest of the consumer. We are not satisfied that the increase is warranted or can be explained or justified on the basis of any objective criteria. The latest proposal by the Licensed Vintners Association raises serious questions about competition and, as the Deputy suggested, the possibility of anti-competitive practices in the drinks industry.

What is also a source of concern is the fact that the vintners take the opportunity around this time of year, each year, to put up their prices. This annual round of price increases seems to operate like clockwork. It is time for the vintners to show responsibility towards consumers in matters of pricing and to fulfil their obligations and duties under our competition laws. Based on the past three budgets, the Government has shown responsibility in its attitude to taxation on drink and we expect a corresponding response from the vintners.

MainHeading.P: It should be pointed out that excise duty rates for alcohol products generally have not been increased since 1989. This was in recognition of the Single Market and the greater harmonisation of prices. There has therefore been a significant real decline in the tax element of drink in recent times. The Government is certainly playing its part. It is regrettable that the retail trade has not responded with equal restraint and regard for the Irish consumer and our tourist trade.

The procedure and methods used by the vintners in their pricing policies certainly need examination. For this purpose, my colleague, the Minister for Enterprise and Employment, has asked the Director of Consumer Affairs to let him have a full and comprehensive report on all aspects of this issue. It will then be for consideration what action to take under the appropriate legislation.
I will refer the other matters, to which Deputy Bruton alluded, to the Minister for Enterprise and Employment, Deputy Quinn, who will take appropriate action, if he has not already done so.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Hip Replacement Operations.

Speaker.P: I thank you, Sir, for allowing me raise this matter tonight. At present more than 300 people, mainly elderly, are awaiting hip operations in Cork city and county and in Kerry. Approximately 2,000 people are waiting for orthopaedic outpatient appointments, which can mean a wait of up to four years.

MainHeading.P: In an attempt to deal with the position the Department of Health and the Minister allocated £2 million to the Southern Health Board to tackle waiting lists. That health board was unable to recruit temporary surgeons to deal with the backlog and the problem was compounded by the fact that the four orthopaedic surgeons in the Cork area, who are employees of the Southern Health Board and are paid by the board, refused to increase their workload. The Southern Health Board had two choices. They could either not avail of the Minister's allocation or subcontract the work, which I proposed they should do. They wisely decided on the latter option and the majority of people awaiting operations, despite reservations about travelling by helicopter to Belfast, are delighted that the end of their painful wait is in sight.

The weekend before last a determined telephone campaign was launched to discredit and undermine the health board initiative. I received seven telephone calls all in respect of the same theme, that the Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast, was not equipped to carry out hip operations, substandard implants were being used, after care facilities were inadequate and Cork doctors on the return of the patients from Belfast would not deal with the patients. This was a reflection on the quality of care in Cork, which I do not accept. I have every confidence in the ability of doctors in Cork, other than the orthopaedic surgeons.

The Irish Hospitals Consultants' Association through its spokesperson has carried out a campaign of misinformation alleging ineptitude on the part of the Southern Health Board management. I have been a critic of the Southern Health Board management in the past when it was justified, but on this issue it has shown foresight, courage and determination in helping the elderly and the sick and carrying out the wishes of the Minister. Allegations that the Southern Health Board was inept in relation to the appointment of the fifth orthopaedic surgeon and the installation of the clean air theatres must be rejected. The Minister will agree that the delay was in the Department and the two decisions were made in the latter part of this year.

The real reason there is such a furore in regard to this matter is that those consultant orthopaedic surgeons employed by the Southern Health Board are also working in private hospitals in the Cork area, the Bon Secours Hospital and Shanakiel Hospital. They have a vested interest in having long public waiting lists because the longer the public waiting list, the greater the demand for their private practice. They are greedy men who are putting their selfish financial wellbeing before the health of their patients. I know of people who are 80 years of age waiting for surgery at present. Those consultant surgeons wish to continue to manipulate the present system for their personal financial gain. Because the Southern Health Board initiative will undermine their lucrative set up, they are attempting to undermine it. What they are doing is possible under the common contract. The present position in an orthopaedic hospital is that, in a 34-bed ward there are 17 patients, in another 34-bed unit there are 11 patients and in a 27-bed unit there are 14 patients. The hospital has the beds and the equipment, but the goodwill and determination of the orthopaedic surgeons is lacking.

I call on the Minister to investigate immediately why there are vacant orthopaedic beds in Cork when the equipment is available and why the surgeons employed in the Southern Health Board will not increase their workload. I appeal to the Minister to review the common contract because it is giving those people the liberty to do what they like. They can mix their private practice with their other work. Their public performance, the work they are paid to do, is suffering as a result, as is the patient.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I thank Deputy Allen for affording me the opportunity of addressing this very important issue. At the outset I would like to outline the background to the board's decision to make arrangements with the Royal Victoria Hospital for the provision of hip replacement surgery.

Earlier this year, I launched a major action programme on hospital in-patient waiting lists. Under this initiative, £20 million is being provided in 1993 to reduce waiting lists where there are long waiting times for admission to hospital. In all, the programme allows for the provision of 17,254 additional procedures nationally this year.

MainHeading.P: The Southern Health Board received a waiting list fund allocation of £1,736,500 in respect of 1,370 additional cases. With the exception of the 300 hip operations at St. Mary's Hospital, Gurranebraher, the health board has indicated that the other 1,070 additional operations for which it has contracted will be met locally.

Delays in implementing the initiative in respect of the 300 hip replacements at the Cork Regional Hospital group were due to difficulties in recruiting a locum consultant orthopaedic surgeon. Despite extensive advertising, no suitable locum could be found. In this regard, the Deputy will be aware that, in August last, I approved the filling of a fifth orthopaedic surgeon post in Cork on a permanent basis. In the normal course, it would take a number of months to have a post filled on a permanent basis, but in the meantime, the health board has, without success, been making exhaustive efforts to fill the post on a locum basis. With regard to orthopaedic facilities generally, the Deputy will also be aware that approval was given to the Southern Health Board in 1992 to provide new clean air theatres at St. Mary's Orthopaedic Hospital, Gurranebraher. Building work, I understand, is due to begin within the next few weeks.

The central feature of the waiting list initiative is that the agreed additional activity targets are achieved. I have stated that where it is clear that targets cannot be met in 1993, for whatever reason, funding will be redirected to other agencies. It was a purpose of the waiting list initiative, which was agreed in the Programme for a Partnership Government that the suffering of those on long waiting lists should be alleviated as quickly as possible.

Finding itself unable to meet the agreed target and mindful of its responsibilities to patients, the Southern Health Board took steps to ensure that 300 patients awaiting hip replacements should not have their suffering prolonged and should not be denied the opportunity provided by the waiting list initiative.

Before entering into a contract with the Royal Victoria Hospital to carry out 300 hip operations over the coming months, I am aware that the Southern Health Board approached all other suitable public and private hospitals in the country but these hospitals were unable to carry out the work in line with the health board's requirements in terms of timeframe and cost.

The health board took the very responsible step of looking further afield in its efforts to help these patients. Surely anyone interested in patient care would applaud them for their efforts. I would like to stress that the option of having the operation carried out in the Royal Victoria Hospital is entirely voluntary, and one for each individual patient concerned. I would also like to stress that the health board has satisfied itself as to the expertise, facilities and quality of care at the Royal Victoria Hospital.

I would like to confirm my support for the speedy and effective action taken by the Southern Health Board in tackling the lengthy public waiting lists for hip operations and I would like to put on record my congratulations to the members of the board, including the Deputy opposite, for their unanimous support for this worthy project.

I am at a loss to understand the constant criticism and apparent undermining by the Irish Hospital Consultants Association, IHCA, of the action taken by the Southern Health Board to ensure speedy relief to a large number of patients who would have been in pain and discomfort for an unacceptable period of time.

I do not think it would be unreasonable to expect a responsible representative medical body to fully support all action taken in ensuring that the target of over 17,000 additional procedures to be carried out in 1993 with the special allocation of £20 million for the national waiting list initiative is met.
The indications at present are that this target will be met bringing enormous benefits to thousands of patients and their families throughout the country.

I wish to inform the Deputy and the House that I am determined to achieve the maximum amount of good with the resources available to me. I will not be deflected by any individual or interest group from achieving this objective.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Escorting of Psychiatric Patients.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Ryan Mr. E. Ryan
Speaker.P: I would like to ask the Minister if he has found a solution to the problem which arose three months ago regarding the escort of involuntary patients to psychiatric hospitals. I am sure he is aware of the recent incident where three psychiatric nurses were stabbed. This incident led to much unease among many people. The Psychiatric Nurses Organisation directed its members not to escort involuntary patients. The present position is complex in that it is difficult to admit involuntary patients to hospital even where a patient's family is trying to have the patient admitted. Unless the patient is willing to go to hospital it can lead to many problems. Some of those people are badly in need of medical care. Health care professionals feel helpless and they hope nothing tragic will occur.

The patients are often a danger not only to themselves but to others. I am sure the Minister is aware that the gardaí have been very helpful and deserve much credit for their work while the Minister tries to resolve the problem. The gardaí will state that they do not believe it is their responsibility and they, like the health care professionals, would like the problem resolved. Everybody realises that it is a very complex problem and appreciates that the Minister is working on it but we would like to find out what progress is being made in order to avoid another accident such as the one that happened a number of months ago.

I was most concerned about the assault on three psychiatric nurses by a patient on 9 July last. It was shocking that three nurses in the course of their work should sustain such terrible injuries. The assault took place while the psychiatric nurses were attempting to return a patient who had been detained for treatment in St. Ita's, Portrane, to the hospital after he had absented himself without leave. I would like to pay tribute in this House to the bravery of the three nurses involved and wish them a full recovery to health.

Following the incident on July 9, I immediately took the following course of action. I requested the assistant inspector of mental hospitals to investigate the circumstances surrounding the assault and to make recommendations in relation to the escort of psychiatric patients. I visited the three injured nurses in Beaumont Hospital, who were making a good recovery from their horrific injuries, and satisfied myself that the Eastern Health Board would provide all necessary support to them pending their return to full health. I met with the unions representing the three nurses — the Psychiatric Nurses Association and SIPTU — and invited them to submit their views for consideration.

The assistant inspector of mental hospitals recently submitted his report on the incident to me. He noted that there was nothing in the previous history of the patient to suspect that a potentially homicidal attack on the three psychiatric nurses would ensue and that the professionalism of the personnel of the various disciplines involved prevented a more tragic outcome. He commended the written procedural policy regarding nursing escorts of St. Ita's, Portrane. He concluded that the assault in question falls into a one in a million category and its extraordinary rarity must in no way be used to put any escort procedure in place that would take from the dignity of patients, increase the unease of the already traumatised relatives, increase the likelihood of danger to escorts or diminish the professionalism of psychiatric nurses.

MainHeading.P: It was noted by the assistant inspector in his report that the psychiatric nurse was the escort of choice and that violence is not usually associated with psychiatric patients. In fact, the incidence of violence in society in non-psychiatric cases far outweighs the violence associated with the psychiatrically ill.

Discussions have also taken place between the assistant inspector, officials of my Department and the Garda Síochána to discuss the respective legal responsibilities of the Garda and the health services in relation to escorting patients. The constraints of the current legal framework were discussed and it was agreed that legal changes were necessary to provide more suitable arrangements for escorting patients to psychiatric hospitals. New mental health legislation is currently being prepared in my Department and will include new provisions in relation to escorting psychiatric patients.

As a result of the assistant inspector's report and my meetings with the unions involved, my Department wrote to each health board on 12 October requesting that the following steps be taken by health boards in relation to each psychiatric service: guidelines for staff involved in escorting patients to be drafted and agreed. These guidelines should define the respective roles of medical staff and nurses in escorting psychiatric patients; appropriate training programmes to be provided for staff involved in escort duties; that the requirements of the health and safety legislation be met in respect of escort duties and, in particular, that safety statements be drafted and agreed; the staffing levels for escort duty in each service to be reviewed; staff on excort duty to be provided with mobile phones; a formal reporting system to be put in place following each episode of escort duty to be provided with mobile made available for staff on escort duty.

Officials of my Department have scheduled a meeting on 26 October 1993 with the two unions representing psychiatric nurses to tell them of the outcome of the assistant inspector's report and of the steps taken to guarantee the greater safety of nurses on escort duties. I will be meeting the union representatives at a later date. I hope that in the light of the assistant inspector's report and the action that I have taken, the members of the Psychiatric Nurses Association employed by the Eastern Health Board will resume escort duties in co-operation with their colleagues in the nursing and medical professions.
The Dáil adjourned at 9.15 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 20 October 1993.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Enterprise Boards Funding.

Qst.Quest: if any funding has been drawn down by the County and City Enterprise Boards; the amount of funding that has been allocated; if there is a regional split in the funding; if so, if he will give the amounts available; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
when funds will be allocated to the Enterprise Boards so that applicants can be paid.

if he will give responsibility for sanctioning all grant allocation including those over £10,000 to the County Enterprise Boards and their evaluation committees in order to avoid unnecessary delay with the sanctioning of projects and added bureaucracy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 33, 35 and 44 together.
I have earmarked up to £250,000 for each board for the September-December 1993 period for the purposes of enterprise support activity.

With a view to avoiding delay in the commencement of the county enterprise initiative and ensuring that local enterprise potential is stimulated at the earliest possible date, the boards have been established on an informal basis, operating within the aegis of my Department on a similar basis to the Western County Development Teams. In view of their informal status in the interim phase it has not been possible, for legal and technical reasons, to delegate budgetary control to the boards. However, I do wish to ensure that the boards will be afforded flexibility in dealing with small projects while ensuring that job displacement is avoided. Accordingly, grants of £10,000 or less will be made to individual qualifying projects by the Minister, following on the recommendation of the relevant County Enterprise Board based on the positive recommendation of its Evaluation Committee. Grants in excess of £10,000 will be made by the Minister, acting on such a recommendation, as endorsed by the County Enterprise Co-ordinating Committee.

I am not aware that delays have been a feature of the operation of the current procedures for ensuring co-ordination among the different State support services. The procedures which have been divised are in accordance with standard public accounting practice and are a necessary means of avoiding duplication and guarding against possible displacement effects on employment levels in the immediate or external environment.

MainHeading.P: In view of particular employment setbacks suffered by the Galway area early in the year, I decided to allocate a special advance provision of £250,000 from the County Enterprise Fund to the Galway City and County Enterprise Board, to be allocated and disbursed through the long established mechanism of the Western Development Fund. Since the formal notification of this allocation to the board, on 29 April last, this special allocation has been fully committed by the board through grants approved by my Department for small economic projects. I am satisfied that the expeditious way in which these applications have been processed will be replicated at a national level in the coming months. I will, of course, be keeping a careful watch on the emerging situation.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he has considered the consumer implications of the recent survey undertaken by the Automobile Association which found that only one in four filling stations were supplying premium unleaded petrol despite the fact that this is suitable for the vast majority of cars and is 10p to 15p per gallon cheaper than super-plus unleaded, and that because all stations sell super plus many motorists were effectively being forced to buy the more expensive brand; the steps, if any, he intends to take to deal with this situation to ensure that motorists/consumers have a proper choice; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I share the Deputy's concern at the findings of the survey in question. I am asking the Director of Consumer Affairs to pursue the matter. It would appear that motorists, and rural motorists in particular, are getting a raw deal. The consumer should at least be given the opportunity to exercise choice as between the two types of petrol in question. It would be a most unsatisfactory situation if petrol companies were exercising this choice on the consumer's behalf.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - NOW Initiative Funding.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the success of the eight community based groups who are funded to participate in the NOW initiative, he will ensure that funding is made available after December 1993 to allow these projects to continue; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: Thirty-two projects have been approved under the NOW Initiative including the projects referred to by the Deputy. Four of these projects will have completed activity funded under NOW by the end of 1993. The remaining four will complete in the course of next year.

Community funding allocated to all the projects supported through the NOW Initiative is for the purpose of initiating specific pilot actions over a predetermined time frame. The overall objective is to support innovatory approaches which focus on facilitating greater access for women to training and employment opportunities in which they are currently under-represented. In this respect the positive experiences gained in implementing projects should subsequently inform the training, education and employment policies of public agencies which are financially supported through the European Social Fund.

Accordingly, project organisers cannot assume, that in the likely event of EC funds being made available under the next Support Framework for Ireland for Initiatives such as NOW, that ESF assistance will be available to prolong existing projects. Such an assumption would run counter to the EC Regulations which govern the funding of approved projects. These do not envisage that the same projects will be indefinitely funded.
A Green Paper on the future of all the EC Initiatives has been widely circulated by the European Commission and comments have been invited. Responses are now being assessed in Brussels.

MainHeading.P: As the responsible Minister, I strongly support the objectives of the three initiatives which deal with the development of human resources — NOW, Euroform and Horizon. Of particular significance is the fact that in Ireland approximately one hundred community and voluntary groups have direct support from the European Social Fund for the first time. They are doing excellent work. I want to afford other groupings who were not included on this occasion because of the inadequacy of available funds an opportunity to benefit in the next round.

I have been in contact with the Commissioner for Social Affairs and Employment, Mr. Padraig Flynn, and underlined the importance and effectiveness of these initiatives. I have every reason to believe that the Commissioner is very favourably disposed. Accordingly, I confidently look forward to the continuation of NOW, Euroform and Horizon and significantly increased Community budgetary provision for them over the period of the National Development Plan, which itself includes references to these three human resource initiatives.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Professional Negligence Compensation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. Walsh Mr. E. Walsh
Qst.Quest: if he will consider the feasibility of capping the level of compensation to be awarded as a result of professional negligence in the same manner as he has proposed in respect of claimants who suffer personal injury as a result of the negligent driving of motor vehicles in view of the High Court settlement in the case of Icarom Ltd. and Allied Irish Banks plc. v. Ernst & Whinney in the sum of $110 million, with its anticipated negative consequences for the cost of indemnity insurance premia for accountants and other professionals; and if not, his reasons for not doing so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: This House will be aware that improving the environment for business is of particular interest to me. In this context, therefore, I would be concerned should any deterioration in the cost structure for business arise, including increases in the cost of professional indemnity insurance.

MainHeading.P: I understand from the insurance industry that it is too soon to say whether or not the settlement referred to by the Deputy will have any effect on the cost of professional indemnity insurance in the Irish market. I would add, though, that it is my understanding that very little in the way of substantial professional negligence cover is written in the Irish market; it tends to find its way to the London i.e. international market, the premia rates for which are determined by developments world-wide. The putative capping of Irish awards, therefore, would be unlikely to have any significant impact on premia for substantial professional negligence covers.

I must remind the House that my statutory responsibility as insurance supervisory authority relates solely to ensuring that insurers meet their statutory solvency requirements. Consequently, I do not have a statutory function in relation to the cost of insurance.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the decision of Packard Electric in Tallaght to issue protective notice to more than 1,000 of its employees, and the potentially disastrous economic implications for the area should these lay-offs be long term, he will give the steps, if any, he intends to take to assist the company to overcome its current difficulties; if the IDA will have a role in this process; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The company has announced that it will introduce a phased reduction in the Tallaght plant's operations commencing on 25 October in addition to implementing a number of temporary lay-offs. These measures are being taken in response to a temporary reduction in orders from the plant's main UK customer in the final quarter of 1992. It is expected that the plant will return to normal levels of activity in January 1994. I am fully aware of the contribution this company made to employment in the Tallaght area over a long number of years and I can assure the Deputy that the IDA is engaged in discussions with the company's senior management aimed at securing the long term future of the Tallaght plant as a viable entity.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Annual Report of Director of Consumer Affairs.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the reason the 1991 annual report of the Director of Consumer Affairs was only published and circulated in October 1993; and his response to the critical comments of the Director expressed in that report about the difficulties being experienced by him being independent in the performance of his functions as required by Statute.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: There has been no undue delay in the publication and circulation of the annual report of the Director of Consumer Affairs for 1991.

I do not accept the suggestion that there are difficulties concerning his being independent in the performance of his functions. Indeed the director's office is well endowed as regards staff and finance, having regard to the current Exchequer constraints.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Leader II Programme.

Qst.Quest: if he will clarify the role and purpose of the county enterprise boards in the context of the Leader II Programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The prospects for Leader II, a successor rural development programme to the present EC Leader Community initiative, hinge upon the outcome of an extensive consultative exercise being conducted by the European Commission on the policy guidelines and priorities for the Community initiatives in the next programming period, 1994-1999. The European Commission is not expected to take a decision on the shape of a new rural development initiative until the end of 1993.

MainHeading.P: The establishment on a national basis of county enterprise boards implements a commitment in the Programme for a Partnership Government. The local enterprise support services to be administered by the new boards have been included among the proposals in the National Development Plan for measures to be financed under the Community Support Framework, 1994-1999. The new boards will complement the work of existing State agencies and will provide a county-wide structure capable of co-ordinating the enterprise related activities of local community bodies.

The decentralisation of decision-making which will be a feature of the operation of the county enterprise boards is consistent with the approach proposed in the Commission's Green Paper on Community initiatives.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Enterprise Boards' Funding.

Qst.Quest: if any private sector funding has been allocated to the county and city enterprise boards; if so, the total amount of such funding; and if he has satisfied himself with the commitment from the private sector.
the basis on which money has been allocated among each of the county enterprise boards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 56 and 77 together.

I have earmarked up to £250,000 for each board for the September-December 1993 period for the purpose of enterprise support activity. The development of criteria for apportionment of funds between the different boards will be addressed in the context of the operational programme for local development under the National Development Plan 1994-1999.

No private sector funding has been directly allocated to the county enterprise boards. However, the financial institutions responded to the Government's initiative by collectively committing funds of £95 million to be used in conjunction with the county enterprise boards.

MainHeading.P: These funds will be available for loans on favourable terms, including no guarantee in the case of incorporated entities and the underwriting criteria will reflect a balanced view of the financial institutions' good commercial practice and social responsibility in playing their part in achieving the aims of the county enterprise initiative in tackling the unemployment problem. I hope this line of support will provide a source of complementary funding to applicants who qualify for grant assistance under the guidelines provided to county enterprise boards. In addition, I am pleased that the banks have confirmed their willingness to provide specialist staff to assist in the evaluation and operation of projects on a “hands-on” basis.

Enterprise projects submitted to county enterprise boards for funding will be evaluated in terms of commercial viability by evaluation committees which will be comprised of, among others, personnel designated by the banks. Officials of my Department will continue to liaise with the financial institutions on the detailed implementation of the scheme. I am satisfied that there will be a continuing positive response from the financial institutions arising from those discussions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Expenditure on Industrial Programmes.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that the level of public spending on industrial programmes is producing adequate return in jobs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: First of all, the Deputy will be aware that public expenditure on industrial programmes extends across a number of different Departments and agencies. Secondly, not all such programmes are directly tied to job creation.

MainHeading.P: I can assure the Deputy that, in so far as my own area of responsibility is concerned, the effectiveness of industrial programmes and the extent to which they are achieving value for money in terms of job creation and other economic indicators are kept under constant review. In this regard the resources of my Department have recently been strengthened specifically to review the effectiveness and value for money of industrial programmes for which the Department has responsibility. The industrial database now available to the Department also enables it to monitor, on an ongoing basis, expenditure in this area. Furthermore, the EC Commission requires that the industrial programmes which are co-financed for Structural Funds purposes under the industry operational programme, are independently evaluated on a continuous basis. The external evaluator's reports are submitted to a Monitoring Committee which is made up of representatives from the Commission, relevant Government Departments, agencies and social partners, and which obviously exists to monitor the implementation of the programme.

The IDA, as the biggest industrial development agency, accounts for a sizeable proportion of expenditure on industrial programmes. IDA grant payments are linked to the job creation performance of companies in a variety of ways. In the case of capital grants, all new grant agreements since 1988 provide for a formal annual review of a company's growth and job creation performance vis-à-vis agreed targets. The release of further grants, or the revocation of grants already paid, is then based on the results of this review. In respect of employment grants, half the moneys involved are paid to the company on creation of the jobs concerned, and half one year later, if the jobs are still in existence.

While the “cost per job” is seen by some as the ultimate measure of the effectiveness of expenditure on industrial programmes, it is, in my view, by no means the only measure against which value for money ought to be assessed, and I intend to ensure that a wide variety of yardsticks are used to assess the effectiveness of our programmes. I am having this whole area reviewed, including the methodology used for calculating cost per job, for this purpose.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Challenge of Single Market.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the 1993 annual report of the SME Observatory, representing small and medium sized enterprises, has concluded that small firms in the manufacturing trading and distribution sectors, particularly in lower income countries such as Ireland, are likely to be the first victims of the EC open market and are particularly likely to be burdened with increased administrative formalities arising from EC rules; and if he proposes to take any action to reduce this competitive disadvantage faced by small and medium sized enterprises in peripheral countries such as Ireland arising from the single market.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the report to which the Deputy refers. The Government recognises that the Single Market, while representing a tremendous opportunity does indeed present a competitive challenge to Irish companies. Both the Government and the EC Commission are acutely aware of the need to take horizontal measures to boost the ability of SME's to compete in a barrier free zone.

The National Development Plan for 1994-1999, just published, acknowledges that indigenous industry here, which is made up almost exclusively of SMEs, suffers from a general lack of competitiveness. Consequently, a key priority of the plan is the development of the indigenous sector. The primary focus of strategy will be on improving the competitiveness of Irish owned industry with a view to achieving an increased share of international and domestic markets, thereby providing a platform for sustainable employment growth.

The new agency for the development of indigenous industry, Forbairt, which will bring together the IDA's indigenous industry functions and the technology development responsibilities of EOLAS, will have a crucial role in the process.

MainHeading.P: In June 1993, I took the initiative in conjunction with my colleague, the Minister of State with responsibility for Commerce and Technology, Deputy Séamus Brennan, in establishing a Task Force on Small Business. The task force which is chaired by the Minister of State consists of the owner-managers of 14 small businesses. Its members therefore have firsthand knowledge of the problems faced by small business. The task force is examining, and will make recommendations on, all of the main issues affecting small firms, including the administrative burdens issue, which the Deputy refers to specifically in his question. It hopes to have completed its work by the end of October. I can assure the Deputy that its recommendations will be given full and prompt consideration.

At EC level, I understand that proposals of the Belgium presidency aimed at accelerating existing EC Commission measures for assisting SMEs are currently under consideration. I further understand that it is the presidency's intention to have these proposals considered at the next Internal Market Council scheduled for 11 November 1993.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in County Waterford who is unemployed but is not entitled to payment of unemployment assistance because he is living at home is precluded from qualifying for all available FÁS schemes as he is not on the live register; if he will review this anomaly; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The employment schemes administered by FÁS are in the main directed at persons on the live register who are long term unemployed and early school leavers. The live register requirement means that expenditure by FÁS on employment schemes is partially offset by savings in social welfare payments.

I have no plans to expand the eligibility criteria for FÁS employment schemes to include persons not on the live register. I would point out that there is no formal live register requirement for participation in FÁS training programmes although priority for places is given to those registered as unemployed. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Vocational Training.

Qst.Quest: if he has established a system of regular surveys to evaluate all training and further education schemes on a consistent basis, to ensure value for participants for the money spent.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The European Social Fund (ESF) programme evaluation unit was established in my Department in January 1992 with financial assistance from the European Commission. The function of this unit is to evaluate the effectiveness of vocational training, education and employment progammes co-funded by the ESF. The scope of the unit's activities extends therefore to all public training and vocational education programmes which receive financial support through the Structural Funds.

MainHeading.P: The work of the evaluation unit involves surveys and interviews with course providers, trainees-students and employers. The current work programme includes a survey of employers to inform evaluations of economic training delivered by the State agencies and a survey of the long term unemployed to inform the evaluation of programmes directed at this target group. An important aspect of the work of the evaluations unit is that the outcome of evaluations is now directly influencing and improving the delivery of national education and training programmes.

As Minister for Enterprise and Employment, my task is to ensure that the considered recommendations made in evaluations influence both the content and the delivery of EC funded programmes. A very significant proportion of the funds assigned in the National Development Plan will be spent on education, training and employment schemes. The valuations to be undertaken throughout the plan period will help to continually improve the quality of training and so greater enhance the prospects of participants in gaining worth-while employment on its completion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)

MainHeading.P: As the Deputy is fully aware, the Shannon region has a first-class base of existing overseas and indigenous firms on which to build and grow. Shannon Development continued to do everything possible to generate a high rate of new firms formation, in addition to maximising the growth potential of existing firms. There are now a range of impressive development assets in place in the Shannon region which are second to none in this country. These include the Shannon Free Zone, the National Technological Park at Plassey, the Shannon World Aviation Park and the Shannon Estuary. Over the coming years, and within the framework of the National Development Plan and the Operational Programme for Industry 1994-1999 it will be possible to continue to develop these key resources not only to regional advantage but also national advantage.

Last year, for the fifth year in succession, Shannon Development achieved a net increase in employment in the industrial areas for which it is responsible. This represents a positive achievement in the current recessionary international business climate and must augur well for the prospects of future growth.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tobacco and Cigarette Sales.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to curb the sale of rolling tobacco and cigarettes which are being sold below the recommended price in Moore Street, Dublin 1; and if tax revenue is being lost as a result of this sale.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that the Customs authorities are fully alert to the situation that prevails with regard to the sale of rolling tobacco and cigarettes without payment of Irish excise duty and VAT in the Moore Street area. During the period July, 1993 to September, 1993, 33.55 kgs. of hand rolling tobacco were seized by Customs and Gardaí from thirty nine street traders in the Dublin area. A further 8.75 kgs. were seized in Dublin Port. During the same period eight seizures involving 23,420 cigarettes were made in the Dublin area. Intelligence gathered by the Customs authorities indicate that most of the tobacco being sold by street traders is imported concealed in consignments of fruit and vegetables which arrive from Continental Europe via Northern Ireland. This intelligence resulted in the seizure of 900 kgs. of Samson tobacco in the Dundalk area on 6th August, 1993. The sale of cigarettes appears to be confined to small quantities which could have been imported under the guise of being for personal use or could have been obtained from crew members of ships in Dublin Port. There is no evidence of any large scale abuse in the sale of cigarettes at present.
I am satisfied that the Customs authorities, with the co-operation of the gardaí, where necessary, are taking all practical steps, on an ongoing basis, to deal with this illicit trade.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Preservation Order.

Qst.Quest: the procedure involved in having a wall and pillar listed for preservation by the Office of Public Works.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Treacy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: There are two forms of legal protection for National Monuments which can be resorted to under the relevant Acts.

Historic monuments and archaeological areas may be afforded legal protection inclusion in the “Register of Historic Monuments”, as provided for under Section 5 of the National Monuments (Amendment) Act, 1987. Such Registrations are carried out on an ongoing basis and details are published in Iris Oifigiúil.

MainHeading.P: National Monuments may also be protected by the making of a Preservation Order, as provided for under Section 8 the National Monuments Act, 1930 as amended by Section 3 of the National Monuments (Amendment) Act, 1954. A Temporary Preservation Order may also be made under Section 4 of the 1954 Act. Preservation Orders are laid before both Houses of the Oireachtas in accordance with the provisions of the Acts.

Qst.Quest: the number of staff employed in the Collector General's office in Limerick; if he will give details of the further phases of the transfer of staff to Limerick; when he expects that the ultimate target of over 550 staff will be reached; the difficulties, if any, that have been encountered in the decentralisation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The decentralisation of the Office of the Collector-General to Limerick involves the relocation of some 550 staff. The Collector General's Office is responsible for the collection of very large amounts of revenue. Given the scale of the project and the need to avoid risks to revenue collection while the transfer is taking place, the project is being implemented in five phases. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - NEC Report.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of figures and tables supplied by his Department to NESC which formed the basis of a table (details supplied) in the NESC report, A Strategy for the Nineties, he will give comparable data in tabulated form for the year 1992-1993 and estimates for the year 1993-1994; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The information sought in respect of 1992-93 is given below. As regards 1993-94 I refer the Deputy to my reply of 6 May 1993.
The Poverty Trap: Man, Wife, Four Children, 1992-93, £ per annum

MainHeading.P: Notes on table:

1. The main components of the Income/Poverty Trap — the apparent decline in net income as gross income increases — are the withdrawal rate of Family Income Supplement (60 per cent) and the operation of marginal relief for income tax (involving 48 per cent tax rate). Both of the measures are designed to achieve desirable objectives in the area of incentives for unemployed persons to take up paid employment, and this is the current policy priority. However, for persons in employment, their operation can give rise to the possibility of an increase in their income being more than offset.

2. It is essential in interpreting this table that the mechanism for reviewing Family Income Supplement (FIS) is understood. FIS is renewable on a 12 monthly basis. Once awarded it will not be reduced/withdrawn until the end of the period regardless of any upward movements in pay. Therefore, gross income from employment can increase significantly during the course of a year while any adjustment of FIS will not occur until after the end of the year. Thus, the FIS withdrawal, represented above as coinciding with gross pay increases does not generally occur.

3. The numbers of people potentially affected by this trap are small. In so far as FIS and marginal relief income tax are the main elements of the trap, the number of people affected by the trap is essentially a function of the numbers who both receive FIS and pay tax. The numbers of people both paying tax and receiving FIS is of the order of 1,500 to 2,000. The OECD has also concluded that this trap potentially “applied only to a very small proportion of the employee workforce (0.75 per cent)”. On the basis of the OECD assessment this would suggest a maximum number of 5,000 to 6,000 persons potentially affected.

4. It should be noted that statistics of income distribution published by the Revenue Commissioners are not a valid measure of the number affected because (a) the data are not desegregated by family size; (b) they include categories such as widows, widowers, single people etc. which are not relevant to the table; (c) the figures are expressed on an annual basis and include people entering employment late in a year, working for short periods or leaving employment early in the year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods

A payment of £5 per week is payable to eligible households from mid-October to mid-April. An additional £3 per week is paid in the Dublin area because of the higher cost of smokeless fuel.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether the FÁS enterprise allowance and the back to work allowance have been integrated with one another, to enable people who have been on the FÁS scheme to continue on to take up the back to work scheme, and to encourage all people undertaking a business start-up to avail of start your own business training courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The back to work allowance scheme, which I recently announced, and the enterprise allowance scheme operated by FÁS are two separate schemes. Periods spent on FÁS courses, including the enterprise allowance scheme, will be counted towards satisfying the elibibility conditions for receipt of the back to work allowance.

People who have completed a period in receipt of the enterprise allowance can then avail of the back to work allowance provided that they satisfy the necessary qualifying conditions of the scheme. These conditions are that the customer must be over 23 years of age, have been unemployed for at least 12 months and have an underlying entitlement to unemployment assistance.

Unemployed people who submit self employment proposals to my Department under the back to work scheme will be advised of start your own business training courses provided by FÁS. They will be encouraged to avail of these courses.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the situation whereby a person who earns £60 and over per week must pay the full rate of PRSI contributions and will not be entitled to the full rate of benefit in the event of sickness or unemployment unless they earned at least £70 per week.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: In 1991 I extended social insurance coverage to all employees earning £25 per week or over. Such employees can as a result of this qualify for the full range of benefits, including pensions. However, in the case of short term benefits it would not make sense to pay the full rate of benefit, currently £55.60 per week for a single person, to someone whose earnings are as low as £25 per week. Such a person would have a strong incentive to give up work and claim benefit instead. In the case of people earning less than £70 per week, therefore some benefits are paid at reduced rates. The threshold of £70 ensures that a single person would have an entitlement to the full rate of £55.60 per week, only in circumstances where the incentive to work is maintained.

MainHeading.P: The PRSI exemption for low-paid workers is a separate feature of the social insurance system. People whose earnings in a particular week are under £60 do not have to pay the employee's social insurance contribution. However, the employer still has to pay the full employer's share, and the employee retains entitlement to social welfare benefits.

Qst.Quest: when he will bring forward proposals to redress the pensions situation for women who are in receipt of contributory pro rata old age pension and who work full time in the home.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: To qualify for an old age contributory pension a person must have entered insurance at least ten years before reaching pension age, have at least 156 contributions paid and have a yearly average of at least 20 contributions registered since January 1953 when the unified system of social insurance came into effect, or the time they started insurable employment, if later.

People with gaps in their insurance may fail to meet the yearly average condition. This can happen for a number of reasons, including leaving employment for periods to care on a full or part time basis for home and family. This situation affects in particular women who work full time in the home, of whom there are some half million.

I plan to bring forward proposals to address the question of pension provision for people in this situation. My proposals will be formulated in the context of the recommendations contained in the final report of the National Pensions Board, which I expect to receive shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Delays in High Court Proceedings.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the widespread concern among persons involved in High Court proceedings at the long delays in having their cases disposed of; and the proposals, if any, she has to expedite such cases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn) Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: I am aware of delays in the hearing of personal injury cases in the High Court and these are matters of great concern to me. It must be noted, however, that since the jurisdiction of the Circuit Court increased in August 1991, the number of personal injury cases being set down in the High Court has decreased by almost 50 per cent, from 10,090 in the 1990-91 legal year to 5,432 in the 1992-93 legal year. This decrease has already reduced the volume of cases awaiting disposal in the High Court. I expect this reduction in volume to continue with a consequent reduction in delays.

Delays in the disposal of personal injury cases can be the result of a variety of factors which are not all court related. I am informed that approximately 90 per cent of personal injury cases are settled out of court.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the recent outbreak of vandalism in Eyrecourt, Ballinasloe, County Galway; if she has satisfied herself that the level of Garda representation in the area is sufficient; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Some of them are being dealt with under the JLO Scheme and I understand that a file is being prepared for the DPP in relation to the others.
