MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Jobs Crisis.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the new strategies, if any, he proposes to deal with the escalating job crisis and the inevitable increases in the number of unemployed following the recent completion of school exams.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. J. Bruton) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The National Development Plan 1994-1999 is a very comprehensive statement of the Government's strategy for tackling unemployment.
The key elements of the strategy directed at strengthening employment performance are
—improving competitiveness, especially in relation to labour costs;
—economic and fiscal strategies that support enterprise, job creation and job maintenance; and
—attacking poverty traps that keep people out of work.

MainHeading.P: Over the plan period it is estimated that about 200,000 jobs will be created in industry, services, natural resource sectors and construction. These jobs are expected to translate into net non-agricultural job growth of between 70,000 and 100,000 over the period of the Plan depending on the level of wage competitiveness improvement achieved and the strength of the growth in the world economy.
Specifically in the case of industry, it is envisaged that some 20,000 gross jobs per annum on average will be created over the Plan period in indigenous industry and through inward investment.

Qst.Quest: the total weekly cost to the Exchequer of the creation of one industrial job in accordance with the projections used to determine the National Development Plan, 1994 to 1999; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: It is not possible, using the methodology currently in use, to provide a meaningful cost per job figure of the kind referred to in the question.
A review of the present methodology is being undertaken at present at my request.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether the FÁS enterprise allowance and the back to work allowance have been integrated with one another to enable people who have been on the enterprise allowance scheme to continue on to take up the back to work scheme and to encourage all people undertaking a business start-up to avail of start your own business training courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The FÁS Enterprise Scheme together with its Business Appraisal Training Programme and Community Enterprise Programme, form the FÁS Integrated Enterprise Programme. The aim of the programme is to assist participants to develop a business idea by training them in business and technical skills and helping to prepare a business plan. The programme is aimed mainly at unemployed people.

Enterprise allowances are offered to support the participants involved in the first period of trading. To qualify for such payments one must have been unemployed and signing on the live register and be in receipt of unemployment assistance, unemployment benefit or disability benefit for 13 weeks immediately prior to joining the scheme. Attendance at a recognised training course is reckonable towards this qualifying period. The business proposed must be potentially viable, fulltime and independent and cannot have started before FÁS approval. Enterprise allowances totalling £40 per week for self employed people without dependants and £65 per week for those with dependants are paid for a period of 40 weeks.

My understanding of the new Department of Social Welfare back to work allowance scheme, in so far as it relates to unemployed persons wishing to enter self-employment, is that the period spent on any FÁS scheme/programme is reckonable in calculating the length of time spent on the live register prior to seeking to participate in the scheme. Accordingly, participation in FÁS enterprise training courses will not adversely affect one's eligibility for the Department of Social Welfare back to work scheme.

Qst.Quest: if he will examine the feasibility of underwriting the insurance risk for very small businesses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: As the insurance supervisory authority I do not have any statutory authority which would permit me to underwrite insurance risks whether for very small businesses or for any business.
The cost of insurance is determined by the frequency and cost of claims and I cannot see that the underwriting of insurance risks by the State would result in a reduction in the cost of claims.
I would add that the Deputy's question does, however, illustrate the need to reduce insurance costs in the interests of job creation and retention.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Health and Safety Inspectors.

Qst.Quest: the number of health and safety inspectors there are; and the area each covers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The number of health and safety inspectors employed by the Health and Safety Authority is 50, broken down by grade as follows: Chief Inspector — one; Deputy Chief Inspector — one; Grade I — nine; Grade II — 18; Grade III — 21.

The inspectorate is multi-disciplinary and contains two divisions, the operations directorate and the specialised services directorate. The operations directorate comprises 31 inspectors and is responsible for enforcement of health and safety legislation and standards in the workplace.

The specialised services directorate comprises 14 inspectors and is specifically responsible for the following: process industries; hazardous substances assessment; occupational hygiene; dangerous substances.

MainHeading.P: The specialised services directorate also encompasses the occupational medical service (OMS) which provides specialist support on occupational health matters. The OMS is comprised of a director and an occupational medical adviser. Three inspectors are currently assigned to non-enforcement duties. These include the development of the authority's information technology programme and the development of new legislation.
A number of the inspectors are based at the authority's regional offices.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to new EC regulations planned to restrict the use of trailers being towed behind cars; the legislation, if any, that is being proposed; and if his attention has been further drawn to the severe restrictions such measures would have on the commercial and farming sectors of the economy and to the possible loss of jobs in the light engineering area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I am not aware of any proposals for new EC regulations to restrict the use of trailers being towed behind cars. Under the EC Motor Vehicle Type Approval system, with which my Department is concerned, member states certify that motor vehicles or component parts thereof are manufactured to specifications as laid down in EC Directives. There are no proposals under the EC Type Approval System for the type of regulations to which the Deputy refers. Neither, I understand, are there any such proposals for new EC regulations in the area of transport legislation.

Qst.Quest: the rules and regulations that exist for a person to practice as a driving instructor; if he has satisfied himself with the present situation; the plans, if any, he has in this regard; if special car insurance is necessary to use a car for the purpose of instruction; the penalties, if any, that exist for failure to do so; the requirements, if any, there are for the establishment of a driving school; the plans, if any, he has in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)
Speaker.P: Apart from the requirement to hold a full driving licence for the category of vehicle in question and have appropriate insurance cover, there are no statutory or regulatory requirements in relation to practice as a driving instructor or the establishment of a driving school. I have no proposals to regulate on a statutory basis the business of providing driving instruction. However, two national organisations representing driving instructors were invited in May 1991 to establish a voluntary registration scheme for driving instructors in association with the Irish Insurance Federation. My Department has offered guidance in this matter and the two bodies concerned have recently submitted an outline plan for such a scheme to my Department. This is being examined at present and a meeting with those bodies will be arranged shortly to advance the matter.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to give local planning authorities the power to cause an immediate cessation of illegal developments; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)
Speaker.P: Planning authorities are empowered by section 26 of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1976, as amended by the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1992, to serve warning notices requiring, inter alia, the immediate discontinuance of unauthorised development or use of land. Failure to comply with a warning notice is an offence, liable on conviction on indictment to a fine not exceeding £1 million or to a term of imprisonment not exceeding two years, or to both a fine and imprisonment. It is also open to a planning authority, or any other person, to apply to the High Court or the Circuit Court, under section 27 of the 1976 Act as amended by the 1992 Act, for an order requiring the discontinuance of an unauthorised development or use of land and the restoration of the land concerned, so far as is practicable, to its previous condition.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: A full round of TB testing is being carried out this year. A small group of counties have shown a relatively high incidence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish Sea Railway Ferry.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, that has been made towards the provision of a railway ferry across the Irish Sea in order to ensure that Ireland will not be further disadvantaged by the completion of the Channel tunnel linking Britain and France; and if he will make a statement on the matter in view of the fact that the option of building an Irish sea tunnel is not being considered because of the prohibitive estimated cost of some £15 billion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: There are no proposals under consideration by my Department for the provision of railway ferry links to either the UK or Europe. A project of this nature would require significant public investment which would not be justified on the basis of the existing and potential volumes of traffic on the rail system. Moreover, it would not be practical, because of rail gauge differences, to run train ferries between Ireland and the UK or Europe. However, the upgrading of rail links from West British ports to the Channel Tunnel is an important element in the Government's strategy for the development of Irish trade and the reduction of the adverse effects of Ireland's peripherality. My Department has been actively pressing for the upgrading of such rail links which are seen as being essential to the integration of Ireland into the community wide transport networks and to facilitate the movement of goods to and from Ireland via the U.K. landbridge and the Channel Tunnel.

MainHeading.P: Under the existing Operational Programme on Peripherality rail connections and ship transfer facilities are being upgraded at a number of ports, on the basis of assistance from the EC Structural Funds. In addition, the National Development Plan which was published recently, and has been submitted to the EC includes provision for the development of the railways and ports on the basis of assistance from the Cohesion Funds and Structural Funds.

Furthermore, as part of an initiative by the European Commission to undertake pilot action studies of links on the European Combined Transport Network, my Department and the UK Department of Transport have agreed that the Ireland/UK/Mainland Europe links should be examined. The European Commission has agreed to co-fund the proposed study. My Department and the UK authorities will shortly appoint consultants to undertake the study which is expected to be completed early next year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drugs Awareness.

Qst.Quest: the efforts, if any, being made to increase awareness among parents and children of the problem of drugs in local surburban communities, particularly in the Dublin area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I am very concerned about the problems that arise from substance misuse in all parts of the country and I readily acknowledge that this problem is particularly prevalent in suburban areas. My Department has in place a number of specific interventions which target young people and parents. These interventions seek primarily to prevent drug misuse problems arising and to combat those which have arisen in the community.

Many of these initiatives aim to raise awareness of the problems posed by drug misuse but they also seek to educate and equip people with skills so that they can make informed decisions and act responsibly.

Most of these initiatives rely on inter-sectoral co-operation for their effectiveness and I set out, hereunder, programmes engaged in by my Department in conjunction with other Departments and non-statutory agencies.
1. Substance Abuse Prevention Programme

This programme is a joint initiative between the Health Promotion Unit and the Psychological Service of the Department of Education with assistance from the Mater Dei Counselling Centre. It is a comprehensive drug education programme which involves the whole school staff of participating schools.

MainHeading.P: This Programme had an extremely successful two-year pilot phase and is currently being revised and will be available on a wider basis from November 1993. The materials consist of five modules — Identity and Self-Esteem; Assertiveness; Feelings; Attitudes and Influences; and Decision Making. The overall aim of the programme is to enable students to develop their ability to take charge of their health and to make informed decisions about the use of drugs in their lives.
2. Pilot Project on Parent Education on Alcohol, Drugs and Family Communication
This programme has been developed by the Health Promotion Unit in conjunction with the Cork Social and Health Education Project of the Southern Health Board.

This project recognises that young people and their parents must be provided with assistance to help them deal with the problems posed by both licit and illicit drugs. To this end, a course is being developed which focuses, not only on drugs themselves, but also on the skills and personal attributes that help people deal with drug situations. These skills relate to such areas as listening; communication; self-esteem; conflict resolution; and discipline.
3. Solvent Abuse Resource Materials

The Health Promotion Unit of the Department of Health in conjunction with the National Youth Council of Ireland has developed Solvent Abuse Materials. These materials were designed for use by such people as youth leaders, instructors of community training workshops, youthreach projects as well as the formal education sector. The contents of the package are also flexible enough for use in special schools, residential centres and as an aid to the Juvenile Liaison Scheme of an Garda Síochána.

The underlying philosophy is that drug and alcohol education is not only about drugs and alcohol but also about people. Thus, while young people need accurate information about drugs, this alone is not sufficient to ensure responsible behaviour. Information must be backed up by assistance in the development of skills in relation to the use of drugs. This incorporates, among other things, the enhancement of self-esteem and decision making skills. Young people also need to examine attitudes to drug use — both their own as individuals and the attitude of the community in which they live. This resource affords the educator the opportunity to do all these things.
4. Drug Questions — Local Answers?

This is a community-based training programme for health/education professionals and others interested in drug-related problems which they meet in their own work. The Health Promotion Unit runs convenor training programmes for this pack in conjunction with the eight regional health boards.
As a result of these courses 400 convenors have been trained to use this pack. The response of those trained in their two-day training programme has been overwhelmingly positive.
5. Educational Materials
The Unit makes available a series of booklets and leaflets on the subject of drugs for both the professional and the general public. Titles available include:
—Understanding Drugs for Parents;
—Understanding Drugs— a booklet for the general public;
—The Facts About Drug Abuse in Ireland— for professionals;
—Solvent Abuse — a guide for professionals and parents.

The whole question of substance abuse is also kept under constant review by the National Co-ordinating Committee on Drug Abuse which is chaired by the Minister of State at the Departments of Health and Justice—Mr. William O'Dea TD.

It is readily acknowledged that an inter-sectoral approach is one that provides the best opportunities for tackling this problem effectively. The inter-sectoral co-operation between the Departments of Health, Justice and Education was significant in preparing and implementing a very wide range of programmes during European Drug Prevention Week 1992. This whole week which had as its aim the reduction of drug misuse among young people will be repeated in 1994 and it is envisaged that similar levels of co-operation among both statutory and non-statutory agencies will ensure the implementation of another successful initiative.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drug Problem.

Qst.Quest: the efforts, if any, being made to increase awareness among parents and children of the problem of drugs in local suburban communities, particularly in the Dublin area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There is a close liaison between my Department and the Department of Health to support schools including schools in the Dublin area, in the introduction of educational programmes on substance abuse. These programmes deal with abuse of all drugs, including solvents, alcohol and tobacco. All schools, both primary and post-primary, and third level colleges, have been provided with information on the abuse of substances.

A major pilot project on substance abuse has taken place over the past two years focused on post-primary schools. This project was carried out with the Department of Health and the Mater Dei Counselling Centre, Clonliffe Road, Dublin and with support from the EC. The outcome of this project, including educational resource materials, are being disseminated to all post-primary schools during the current school year. A programme of inservice training for teachers will be included with the dissemination.

MainHeading.P: My Department also co-operates with the regional health boards and voluntary agencies such as youth organisations and parent groups in initiatives aimed at alerting young people to the dangers of substance abuse. In all projects undertaken schools and teachers are advised to consult parents and to inform them of the educational activities in schools.

My Department is represented on the Government's Co-ordinating Committee on Drug Misuse and contributes to the development of the national strategy to prevent such misuse. As a result of the work of this committee initiatives are kept under review and new initiatives planned.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a request from the Galway City Vocational Education Committee that an additional school bus be authorised to facilitate transport for 17 pupils from the Moycullen area in County Galway who attend second-level colleges in Galway city; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I have received no request from the Galway City Vocational Education Committee in relation to the matter raised by the Deputy. However the issue has been brought to my Department's attention by the local transport liasion officer. The reasons an additional school bus cannot be authorised in this case were set out in my response to the Deputy's question of 6 October, 1993.

Qst.Quest: the criteria used to exempt primary schools from the payment of television licences; the number of schools which are exempt from payment at present; and the plans, if any, she has to exempt all primary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: In the interests of clarity, I should point out that no primary school which has a television receiving apparatus is exempt from payment of a television licence. I understand that new legislation would be necessary in order to exempt schools from the purchase of TV licences. Such legislation would be a matter for the Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht and I have asked officials of my Department to take up this matter with that Department.

In the meantime, as an exceptional measure, I have agreed to refund the cost of such licences purchased by schools in designated areas of disadvantage in the current year. This facility is available to the 258 primary schools currently included in the disadvantged areas scheme and is based on a recognition of the particular difficulties faced by such schools in meeting their financial commitments. I have no plans to extend this arrangement to all primary schools.

Qst.Quest: if she will provide financial assistance to St. Paul's CBS, North Brunswick Street Primary School, Dublin 7, to help cover the costs arising from vandalism (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There is no application on hand from the school authorities in question for a capital grant. Any costs above those covered by the school's insurance in this case would fall to be met by the school authorities out of its capitation grant receipts as glass replacement is a maintenance item.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to improve facilities at the Boys national school, Carrick-on-Shannon, County Leitrim; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department is in consultation with the school authorities regarding the possible amalgamation of St. Mary's boys' national school with the convent girls' national school. This is because preliminary indications are that there probably would be sufficient accommodation in the convent national school to accommodate the entire boys' and girls' primary school population in Carrick-on-Shannon in future years.
Pending the outcome of these discussions my Department has sanctioned a grant in respect of essential remedial works to the boys' national school.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Mayo School Transport.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach

Qst.Quest: if a new school building will be provided for Derrywash School, Castlebar, County Mayo; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed, in principle, to provide new classrooms at this school, and the preparation of the schedule of accommodation is under way. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Payment of ESF Grants.

Qst.Quest: when payment of ESF grants will be issued to students in County Wexford and, in particular, to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford; and if she will expedite early payment of such grants in view of the cashflow difficulties of students' families.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I understand from Carlow Regional Technical College, which is the body responsible for the payment of ESF maintenance grants in this case, that the relevant payments will be made to first year students, including the person in question, by the second week of November 1993.

I am very conscious of the effects of delays in grant payments on students and their families, and I accept that this is an area which needs to be improved. I am looking forward to receiving the report of the expert advisory group which I set up earlier in the year to examine the student support system. The terms of reference included recommending the most efficient organisational arrangements for the delivery of the system. The group's report is due shortly.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if she will provide a sports hall, pavilion, and showers for PE instruction at a school (details supplied) in Dublin 6W with 912 pupils; if she has received representations to do this; is her consideration of this application adequate; if she will confirm that the facility will be provided; and if she will give priority to providing the facility in view of the fact that the school has a huge number of pupils and is located in an area of high demand for secondary places.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There have been recent representations regarding the provision of PE facilities for this school. Due to demands on the capital resources available, priority has been given for some time to the provision of essential teaching spaces. As a result it is not possible in present circumstances to grant aid provision of physical education facilities at existing schools without such facilities. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Donegal Resource Teachers.

Qst.Quest: the primary schools in County Donegal who have applied for a resource teacher, the schools that have already been allocated such a facility; the criteria employed in deciding eligibility; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department has an application for a resource teacher to be shared between the following group of schools in the Letterkenny area of County Donegal: Illistrim national school, Scoil Muire gan Smál, Scoil Cholmcille, Scoil Talamh na Coille, Scoil Mhuire, Baile na nGallóglach and Glenswilly national school. The creation of additional resource teacher posts in national schools in a particular year depends upon the teaching resources which can be made available in that year.

MainHeading.P: The role of the resource teacher is to support the ordinary teaching staff in meeting the special needs of handicapped children attending ordinary classes. When posts become available they are allocated on the basis of priority of need, following the collection of data from schools by my Department's primary inspectorate. At present, there are seven special resource teachers appointed by my Department. These teachers are based in the Cahirciveen, Clonakilty, Carrick-on-Suir, Clifden, Tuam, Gorey and Newbridge areas. While no resource teacher appointments have been made to date in 1993, the question of further such appointments is being actively considered. The needs of the schools in question will be considered in this context.
